intro: Desmotrichum pemae, commonly known as the Pemá's desert lily, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of South America. It belongs to the family Amaryllidaceae and is characterized by its striking, trumpet-shaped flowers that bloom in the evening. The plant has a short, robust stem and produces clusters of narrow, grass-like leaves. It is adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments through deep root systems and water-storing tissues. Its flowers are typically white or pale pink, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths.
